text: Healthcare Professional: Yep. Doctor: And, she’ll go over all the, the, the other detail, which you’ve already read. You know, this is the opportunity for you to ask me questions and see if there is any reason that you want to abort, uh, or say this is the right way to go. Uh, and, then, I’ll get your medicines written and plan for your hormone shot in two weeks. And, then, we can leave it a little bit up in the air between T_, myself, as to what, uh day per our calendar when you wanna just say, “Okay, this is…” Patient: Well, well, well, we’ll work within that, that four-week window of the month. That has to start with - I just, again, if we, if the advice was to start same day, I would. If you wait four weeks, we will pick a date four weeks out and start then. Doctor: Yeah, and if he had a little bit more flexibility, just again, if we started then, and it ends up on Christmas and the holidays. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: From when I talk to people, first dose of chemo, most of the guys that I talk to, not a huge impact effect with nausea or, or anything. Um, it was the second or third that they really started to feel um - Doctor: In my experience, the first cycle is the hardest in some ways, ‘cuz you just don’t know what to expect. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, when am I gonna feel tired? They told me I’m going to have aches. They told me this, and then if it happens or some of it happens. Uh, so we’re trying to give you. But usually, that first cycle sorta gives you your pattern. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I felt good, and then I felt tired, and then I was really wiped out, I had to sleep a lot that week and then I felt really good and they had to do it again. (laughter) Patient: Where would I find that information?

text: Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So there there isn’t a but you’re not getting any therapy or you’re getting only a pla-placebo potentially. So, in response to what you just said which is you you wanna get some drug back into your system- Patient: Yup. Doctor: That the clinical trial will give you the option of doing that um potentially with something experimental out and on- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But not necessarily. Um just a couple of words about the side effects and they’re all listed in this consent form which is fourteen pages long, so it’s quite detailed. But um the main side effects are listed in section four and I will read that with you so you can look at it. We have seen some fatigue with this medication. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We have seen some nausea in some people. We have some seen some rash, you know a few people ten to fifteen percent. Um we are going to keep a very close eye on your liver function and kidney function to make sure that those weren’t affected by the drug. Uh some people have a uh worsening of their hot flashes, because of the Xtandi itself cause worsening of the hot flashes. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um some people can have a uh decreased energy or they might feel more tired. Um but I, I would have to say in general these side effects are all better than what we see in chemotherapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: So it it it does seem to be the best

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Now, we’ve probably told you this before including me, myself, telling you this. That when you are taking an experimental drug, that’s not a hormonal therapy, in this case it’s . Uh, just because the PSA is going up, doesn’t necessarily mean the drug is not working, although when the PSA is dropping, we certainly always interpret that as a good sign. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, and your PSA over the last three months has continued to go up. Uh, and so that’s one thing. Uh, on the other hand, you know, the scan that you had on August the first and August the second showed that the cancer seems to be relatively stable. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The thing that has concerned us before was that you were getting this sort of worsening bone pain in the left thigh bone and the lower spine and the left ribcage, which sounds like you’re still having those to some degree. They don’t sound as constant. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, based on your interpretation, perhaps they’re a little bit better. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not putting words in your mouth. Uh, so before I came in to see you today, I was kind of planning to say like this doesn’t look like it has been working that well, maybe we should switch to something else. After speaking to you, and hearing it from you, I’m kind of backtracking a little bit and I’m beginning to think like maybe we should give this a chance to work a bit longer. Um, you certainly haven’t had like the best possible response that we could have expected. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We have seen patients who, even in the first two months, their PSA level drops by fifty percent, and the tumors begin to shrink. We certainly haven’t seen that. On the other hand, we haven’t seen like an obvious, uh, progression of the cancer either on the scans. So I would say, you know, you’re certainly not the best case scenario on this medication, but you’re by no means the worse, either, somewhere in the middle, and so that’s why I needed some input from you as far as what you think we should do. I’m willing to stick with this a little bit longer. We don’t want to wait too long so that, you know, if something bad happens like one of your bones fractures or pain gets excruciatingly worse, uh, and so, and on the other end of the spectrum as well, your anemia is still there, so your hemoglobin level was still below nine. It was about eight point nine, uh, on the most recent check, and even if we decided to continue on this study at the very least between now and your next visit- is that September fourth? Family Member: Fifth.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, the issue that you run the risk is if it does show up and we'll catch it early or you're aware of it and it pops up in your lung. Patient: Yes, that’s not good. Doctor: That's something that can be associated with pain or sudden death. Patient: Right. That's right. My sister in law died of that. Healthcare Professional: Oh, I’m so sorry. Doctor: Not blood? Patient: Not blood, no. That's all I know about it. I mean, I just know that it’s not a good thing. Healthcare Professional: Oh. Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. text: Patient: I feel so; I, I uh I govern that by my ability to you know do things around the house. So whether it’s supporting activities, playing golf I don’t have any energy. And possibly because I’m a little heavier now, too. I’ve gained a few pounds. Doctor: Now are you still trying to be as active as possible, for example, golf or other activities? Or has that been slowing you down? Patient: I’m trying, but I just don’t have the energy. Doctor: Okay, uh any other issues with hot flashes or night sweats? Patient: No, no. Not night sweats, but I do recognize that at times I’m sitting in church and for some reason I just start where other folks are you know are just perfectly calm and cool. Doctor: So during the day just out of the blue? Patient: Yeah, just out of the blue. It last for a few minutes and then stops. Doctor: Okay, on an average day how many times does that happen or is it not every day? Patient: When I’ve noticed it, it might be once or twice a day. Doctor: Okay, all right. Usually not at night, usually during the day. Patient: No, no. Well it could be the stress or the activity that’s happening in church that might push my level. Doctor: Well your testosterone level is still low. Patient: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Huh, so normally what you would end up doing is stopping the four pills. You can stop that. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
